column1: Sequels: 45855 “I’ll be right back,” I said softly to the injured angel. [SEP] The Bonesetter would know what to do. [SEP] I stood and ran briskly across the field to the road. [SEP] The Bonesetter lived not far away from my house, in a once-colorful gypsy caravan where he did his work. [SEP] As a child, I had been terrified of the caravan, partly because the Bonesetter growled and snapped at the village children, but also because of the blood-curdling screams that
column3: from inside when people were having their broken bones set, so they would heal properly. [SEP] Breathless, I arrived at the caravan door, and knocked sharply upon it. [SEP] I knew that the Bonesetter would not answer unless it was an emergency, so I kept knocking until he opened the door and snarled, “What is it you want that you must make such a racket on my door?” “You must come,” I said, gasping. column1: EP] Rachel was standing with a plastic cup, looking like she was having a conversation, but I couldn’t see anyone else there. [SEP] The next time the crowd split, I saw him. [SEP] He stood in front of a blue light, so I couldn’t see him clearly, but what I saw was memorable. [SEP] He wore a jacket of what might have been blue velvet, and his hair gleamed black against his white skin. [SEP] The blue haze seemed to stop just shy of his pallor, setting off his striking face without illuminating its details, and his wrists flashed white in the darkness. [SEP] He didn’t move, just stared and held his drink. [SEP] The next time I saw them, his mouth was moving. [SEP] She nodded and he took her arm. [SEP] I watched them through the crush of dancers as they squeezed along the wall, and the feeling
column3: to me that something was very wrong. [SEP] Saturday morning, I woke up and saw that she still hadn’t come home. [SEP] A couple of them remembered seeing her leave, but none of them had seen the thin man with her. [SEP] I didn’t know how they could miss such exotic features, even in that distorting light.

It almost looked like the light bent around him without actually touching him directly. He was slim, almost drawn, but he had a kind of … luster to him, I guess. He wasn’t a person you’d describe with normal adjectives, you know?”

column1: [SEP] He pointed at the wall to our right. [SEP] “Don’t let the sun fool you. Then I’m going to shed a little blood, but don’t worry, none of yours.” [SEP] I blinked at him, but he just kept walking until we reached the corner. [SEP] “Okay, you might feel silly, but just turn three times to your left. Try to keep in time with me.” [SEP] We spun around three times, and then something flashed across Nepthys’ hand and he shook a spray of blood onto the dust. [SEP] The blood flashed into flames as soon as it hit the ground, and I jumped back. [SEP] When it had all burnt, a thin outline of a doorframe appeared on the wall across from our corner. [SEP] Nepthys walked towards it and pressed his bloody palm against it, opening the door. [SEP] “Are you coming?” [SEP] We slipped through the door and
column3: out, not inside the building, but on a busy street in a completely different part of town. [SEP] The sky, cupping over squat buildings, was less yellow here, and stands were set up everywhere the way I’d picture a market in the Middle East. [SEP] Nepthys took us immediately to the right, where he led us to a cart filled with herbs. [SEP] Spiced air hanging around the cart carried tarragon, rosemary, and scents I couldn’t place. [SEP] The thing tending the cart reminded me of the caterpillar from Alice in Wonderland: it had the same opium-dream wise man quality I’d always given the caterpillar. [SEP] Its arms were thin and long enough to reach any herbs from its cushion in the center of the cart, and with its long, many-shouldered pole of a torso, it rose over our heads even while seated. column1: The latch opened under Nepthys’ left hand with a clack! [SEP] The door took us to the bottom of a flight of wooden stairs. [SEP] At the top was one door. [SEP] We entered. [SEP] The room held a bed, a bookcase, and a desk with one chair. [SEP] Its only light
column3: from a dying candle on the desk whose spark etched shadows in the roughly planked walls. [SEP] On the bed was a small, ratty man. I smelled matted hair and cedar chips. [SEP] He opened one eye when we

column1: “Marvelous!” cried the woman. [SEP] “One half-pint of human blood, willingly given, and his fine head of hair for the stone.” [SEP] She took us downstairs to a small room behind a red silk draping. [SEP] There was a wooden chair, where she sat me down and asked me to wait. [SEP] Soon, she
column3: back with a lidded ceramic bowl, which she put on the table beside me. [SEP] “Roll up your sleeves,” she told me. [SEP] She opened the bowl and carefully, gingerly brought out a fat, dripping leech. [SEP] It must have been larger than my finger. [SEP] She laid it gently inside the hollow of my left arm. [SEP] The cold thing stretched and cast around with its sucker-mouth until it found the soft spot inside my elbow, where it softly sucked on and began to work its way under my skin. [SEP] I thought that I could feel a slight itching. [SEP] “They take about a quarter-pint each,” said Madame Entera, drawing out another skinny leech. [SEP] “They’re quick, too. We’ll be done with them before your hair is finished.” [SEP] Then she clapped her hands and brought in the barber.

column1: That made me a little sad. [SEP] They were always my favorite part of the Greek myths I read in elementary school. [SEP] “Well, what about you? How did you get to America?” “My parents
column3: over from Russia, just like your family. My real name is a little more ethnically appropriate, but we don’t toss those around in this place. They were spirits of a certain branch of the Volga and the village based around a mill on that tributary. When the Russian government dammed the river, my parents decided that instead of dying with the river, they would stick with the people of the village they’d protected. I was born here, and I was lucky enough not to get attached to any particular river. Sure, I miss having a place to settle down, but it’s better than waiting to get dammed.” [SEP] He took another shot of vodka. [SEP] “Shouldn’t you be going light on the vodka? I mean, we might have a lot of work ahead of us.”

column1: Immediately, I felt it grow warm and knew that I had done something very stupid. [SEP] “Nathan,” said Nepthys, “I think that you just did something very stupid.” “I agree,” I told him. [SEP] The stone was as warm as human flesh now, and there was a sort of glow that might have been light or just the stone’s soft heat, I don’t know. [SEP] Then there was light, a kind of rosy glow, and I felt the stone slip out of my hand to float in the air. [SEP] The air around me seemed to still sound, and light
column3: in around the corners of my eyes. [SEP] “Do you know what this thing does?” [SEP] I shouted, hardly able to hear myself. [SEP] Nepthys was saying something that looked like, “I have no idea!” but I couldn’t hear him. [SEP] The light in the corners of my eyes rushed in, converging on the rosy glow around the stone, and for a moment I was blind. [SEP] Then I opened my eyes again and saw a girl lying in the street. [SEP] There was no sign of the stone.

column1: that you have! Fools! Get out of my sight now – unless you know how to put it back? …I thought as much. Now leave, before I call the rats on you.” [SEP] We left. I should say, set yourself back, since it’s your girlfriend we’re looking for.” [SEP] I thought about Rachel; in the excitement, I had forgotten why we were chasing down vampire experts. [SEP] “You’re just lucky that Dvorov isn’t my only contact. Come on, we’re heading out.” [SEP] He held the door for me and Amy when we reached the bottom of the stairs. [SEP] Walking outside, I was shocked to see that it was already dark. [SEP] “Night comes quickly here,” said Nepthys quietly as he
column3: out behind me. [SEP] “Didn’t I warn you?” “Okay,” he said as we hit the street, “we’re going to see another friend of mine. First, though, we are getting you a hat. You look ridiculous with a shaved head.” [SEP] At a nearby stand, he grabbed the first hat that would cover my head and might pass back in real Boston. [SEP] It was a black baseball cap that read “Dead Can Dance” in gold across the front. [SEP] Amy liked it, I think. [SEP] She still hadn’t spoken since I named her, so I wasn’t sure.

[SEP] “I’m here to see Isis. Tell her that Nepthys is here to see her.”

column1: Something with too many arms was manning the turntables above the crowd, which looked more impenetrable tonight than ever before. [SEP] Then I saw the bar on the other side of the crowd and knew where to start looking. [SEP] I tried to slip along the edge of the crowd. [SEP] Things with scales and claws kept flailing against me, pressing me into the wall, but I took a breath and kept moving. [SEP] My nose filled with a reek of thick sweat. [SEP] The music began to build, and a strobe
column3: on. [SEP] Somewhere toward the center of the dance floor, I heard a howl that sent bitter winds under my clothing – for a second, I was back with my family in Russia, hiding from the cold. [SEP] Then I felt a tug on the back of my shirt and noticed that Amy was following me. I gathered her under my arm. [SEP] Dvorov was somewhere behind me, too, negotiating delicately through his patrons. [SEP] Just in front of me, a massive thing slammed into the wall, sending up a cloud of granite dust. [SEP] It slumped to the floor and I realized that it was a werewolf. [SEP] Its haunches twitched in time to the music. [SEP] As it started to rise, a man with thick, scaled skin stretched across rippling muscles leapt on him. [SEP] I thought that my odds were better on the dance floor.

column1: We chased after him, Amy keeping up valiantly behind us. [SEP] He bashed up a set of stairs set into the side of the wall, and we chased up after him, heading up a huge staircase that seemed to go up for more stories than the building could have held. [SEP] Luckily, the vampire turned off after three stories. [SEP] He ran down a hallway and slipped behind one of the doors, but Nepthys was close behind him and left it open for me. I called out to Amy to shut the door in case the vampire had any friends who might be trying to follow us. [SEP] Inside was a dark room that looked like a storage space for DJ equipment. [SEP] Nepthys urged me on from the back of the room, then made a turn out of sight. [SEP] When I
column3: to the door at the end of the room, it looked like it had been torn off its hinges. [SEP] I didn’t imagine that Nepthys had done it, and it wasn’t without alarm that I ran after him. [SEP] A black hallway opened into a space like a cathedral. [SEP] The vault rose into obscurity above me, and a massive rose window stood ahead of me. [SEP] The panes looked dyed black, and only a few cold beams slipped through the filter. [SEP] Footsteps echoed through the stone chamber, and the sound reflected back to me from everywhere. [SEP] I couldn’t tell how many people were running, much less where they were. [SEP] On the steps in front of the altar, I saw pale forms and realized that they were Rachel and two other women. [SEP] Then I heard Nepthys shout, “Nathan! Behind you!” [SEP] I whirled and droppe

column1: I was content to let myself drift away, and I had almost forgotten the body lying with broken neck on the cathedral’s hard tiles when I felt a warm touch on its cheek. [SEP] A girl’s voice, soft and almost recognizable, spoke, “Nathan.” [SEP] I felt my head turn and something in my neck reconnected. [SEP] Then my eyes opened and Amy handed me the hammer and stake. [SEP] I stood and turned toward the altar. [SEP] The vampire was walking just steps ahead of me. I stepped up behind him and raised my hands, which almost seemed to be glowing. [SEP] Then the stake
column3: down into his back and one, two, three strikes with the hammer drove it in. [SEP] The vampire fell forward and blood began to flow from his mouth. [SEP] Behind me, Amy was kneeling beside Nepthys, whose arm and rib cage were knitting back together like a wooden toy that falls apart when its string is released but draws itself together at a slight tug. [SEP] I pulled the vial of liquid that he’d been giving me from his pocket and ran to the altar.

column1: The Black Willow Allan sat down at his desk and pulled the chair in close. [SEP] Opening a side drawer, he took out a piece of paper and his inkpot. [SEP] After filling his pen, Allan looked at his paper in the orange glow from the lantern set back in the desk's right-hand corner. [SEP] His pen cast a forbidding line of shadow slanting across the page, echoing the inky darkness crouching in the edges of the lantern's struggling glow. [SEP] The only other illumination
column3: from a lurid moonlight filtered through thin branches and clouds, casting its bone-pale glow onto the pine floorboards. [SEP] Allan unfolded another page, this one crowded with ranks of letters in tight formation from left to right. [SEP] The lines of letters stepped into their divisions, in the shape of a story's outline: the loose, dry skeleton of a tale lay exposed beneath their feet, awaiting tendons, muscle and blushing skin. [SEP] Allan reviewed the troops, all prepared to disembark, their task to form the tale of a young man returning home from Life Abroad to find his childhood friend a bride to-be, thus upsetting the apple cart of his life's plan, clarified – of course – by his very time away from her he loved best.

column3: over me and I started writing like Edgar Poe – though the most recent was not so morbid as my many others, thank Heaven." [SEP] "I'm not familiar with Mr. Poe's works, but I assume you're referring to your unhealthy penchant for the fantastic."

column1: They parted and Allan made his way pensively from Arthur's gate. [SEP] He walked the wheel-ruts, hands in his pockets and unshined shoes collecting dust. [SEP] Some quarter-mile from Arthur's gate, he halted, confronted by a halloo. [SEP] "Nathan?" he called out to the empty road. [SEP] The reply
column3: from above him and Allan turned to see his friend reclining in the fork of a great tree. [SEP] "I had a hunch you'd be at Arthur's today," said Nathan, "so I thought I'd wait here for you." [SEP] Nathan's lanky frame, dressed in a loose, tan jacket, fit into the branch like an elegant skeleton. [SEP] His hair fell loosely across a face that seemed always to have a knowing smirk hidden just beneath its surface, infusing his body with a rakish energy. [SEP] "So, Allan," said Nathan, unfolding and lowering his legs to the roadside, "how goes life for the quintessential American author?" "I wouldn't know," replied Allan dryly, before continuing in another tone entirely. [SEP] "I destroyed another story last night, Nathan."

A young girl who was writing a paper for school
column3: to her father and asked, "Dad, what is the difference between anger and exasperation?" [SEP] The father replied, "It is mostly a matter of degree. Let me show you what I mean." [SEP] With that the father went to the telephone and dialed a number at random. [SEP] To the man who answered the phone, he said, "Hello, is Melvin there?"

column1: See, said the father to his daughter. [SEP] "That man was not a bit happy with our call. He was probably very busy with some-thing and we annoyed him. Now watch...." [SEP] The father dialed the number again. [SEP] "Hello, is Melvin there?", asked the father. [SEP] "Now look here!"
column3: the heated reply. [SEP] "You just called this number and I told you that there is no Melvin here! You've got a lot of nerve calling again!" [SEP] The receiver slammed down hard. column1: The White House said President Bush has approved duty-free treatment for imports of certain types of watches that aren't produced in "significant quantities" in the U.S., the Virgin Islands and other U.S. possessions. [SEP] The action
column3: in response to a petition filed by Timex Inc. for changes in the U.S. Generalized System of Preferences for imports from developing nations. [SEP] Previously, watch imports were denied such duty-free treatment. [SEP] Timex had requested duty-free treatment for many types of watches, covered by 58 different U.S. tariff classifications. column1: y workers regularly meet for lunch or after work. [SEP] In these meeting places, people gather to see old friends, gossip, and make new acquaintances. [SEP] In the workers’ adopted social settings, the transition from friendly chatter to serious business occurs naturally. [SEP] In the Silicon Valley, collective actions unfold through a combination of mutual interests, intellectual curiosity, and problem solving geared towards developing new markets, technologies, products, or applications for computers. [SEP] Workers have a systemic commitment to technical excellence in their field. [SEP] As one engineer explained, the process is quite simple: ‘people rub shoulders and share ideas’ (Saxenian, p. 27). [SEP] The knowledge of these informal groups is so powerful that many ‘local entrepreneurs
column3: to see social relationships and even gossip as crucial aspects of their business’ (Saxenian, p. 26) As one local manager claimed: ‘‘‘Over a lunch conversation or a beer, you’ll learn that company A or company B has a technology you want . . . If it fits your needs, you’ll build it into your next product’’’ (Saxenian, p. 31). [SEP] In this manner, micro-level conversations influence the creation of new technologies, products, and applications. [SEP] It is through such social interaction and collective action that we begin to understand how patterns and order emerge in the Valley. [SEP] In the absence of hierarchy and centralised planning, employees in the Valley rely on their skills, rather than on formal position, to provide a reference point for their careers. column1: o the United States from South Africa, Greenberg was employed writing design standards for courthouses, which led to an unusual commission: the conversion of an empty supermarket into a courthouse. [SEP] He gave the commercial building in Manchester, Connecticut, a new façade dominated by a large arch, over-scaled voussoirs, and a pediment. [SEP] Inside, the barrel-vaulted ceiling of the lobby was supported by a Tuscan order. [SEP] Greenberg had graduated from Yale in 1965, and like many of his contemporaries was experimenting with the new freedom offered by Postmodernism. [SEP] However, unlike Venturi and Moore, Greenberg was not coyly introducing Classical elements into a Modernist building; he was returning to Classical roots. [SEP] From this modest beginning, over the next two decades,
column3: a variety of commissions: a suite of rooms for the Secretary of State in the United States Department of State building, several college and university buildings, and a Roman Catholic church. [SEP] His commercial work included a newspaper office building in Athens, Georgia, a new entrance for Bergdorf Goodman on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, and a flagship store for Tommy Hilfiger in Beverly Hills. [SEP] Greenberg is also known for large country houses, both in the United States and in Europe. [SEP] Like Lutyens and John Russell Pope, he ventures stylistically farther afield in his residential work—using Georgian and American Colonial styles.
